Author: goibnu

Comment: Yeah we do   We’re likely going to be pretty happy with it - reduced tariffs for our steel and car exports, we don’t have to accept your stupidly low food quality standards, and in return we have to reduce tariffs on your cars which very few people will buy anyway because they’re too large for our roads and laughably uneconomical for our fuel costs. Also we’re probably knocking off a bit off our digital services tax that your massive companies like Amazon and meta pay but it isn’t going away completely according to rumour.   Trump is calling it a comprehensive deal but really it’s a few points knocked off some obvious areas of cooperation.   Shows he’s desperate for a win to announce because previously any deal with the U.S. has been held up by the US insisting on the UK accepting lower food standards as the price of entry, and Trump was still asking for that even a couple of months ago. Now apparently it’s not quite so important.
Author: Drolb

Regardless I hope Starmer has played a blinder in this deal (or the concept of one) and used Trumps desperation to save face
Author: PenitentGhost

Comment: The trade surplus is what he’s after. He heard that probably in a meeting and wants to use that to sell the public his whole “trade wars are easy” rhetoric. He’ll definitely take ownership of the surplus as a result of his policies while the Brits blink and shrug and agree to better terms for themselves. One thing though, I haven’t read anything in this deal about American health insurance companies. I’ve read a few past articles of these companies trying to gain better access in the UK and in these same articles there were conservative MP’s wanting to do away with the NHS and replace it with an American system. Yes, what a horrible idea so it’s easy to assume Trump would push this with the backing of the American insurance lobby. I just haven’t read anything about it in this sudden announcement of this agreement.
